projectDesc.p: The Middle English Texts Series offers a diverse and representative array of literary texts that medieval readers in the present-day British Isles would have encountered between the twelfth and sixteenth centuries. It is committed to making available both affordable print and open access editions to scholars, teachers, and students of the Western Middle Ages. In its digital publications, the series prioritizes a user-friendly interface and viewing options, multiple downloadable formats, enhanced searchability and filtering, and accessibility to the widest possible range of users.

editorialDecl.p: METS takes as its mission the creation of affordable editions that would pass scrutiny from the most demanding expert, yet would prove comprehensible, and even enticing, to someone who had never read Middle English before. This agenda dictates that METS publications offer not a critical edition reflecting all surviving manuscripts, and certainly not a diplomatic edition, but a best-text edition, informed by the notes and apparatus of earlier editions (where these exist), and by substantive variants from other manuscript witnesses. Transcriptions of Middle English texts are lightly modernized to ensure a smooth reading experience, while non-English texts preserve both the original language and a modern English translation in facing-page format. Each edition offers expert assistance with language and lexicon, providing glosses alongside the text(s), textual and explanatory notes, elucidation of unfamiliar contexts and traditions, and thematic and interpretive possibilities. All editions feature general introductions that set the edited text within its own time, place, and traditions, and link it to ancestor, congener, and successor materials. All publications contain comprehensive, current bibliographies of pertinent scholarship and criticism. House style is adapted from the Chicago Manual of Style.

correction.p: This text may include corrections made after the original edition went to press in order to correct errors and improve glosses. div.head: Prologue
div.ab: [fol. 203r] SeyntT Poul the apostilN seith that alle tho that wilne pitousli lyvenG in Jhesu Crist schullen suffre persecucioun and anguyschis.N But oure swet Lord Jhesu Crist wil not that his chosenT faileG in tribulaciouns.Therfor he coumfortith hemG of hymself and geveth vertueG to his grace and seith to hem, “Have ye no drede. I am with you al dayes to the endyng of this world,N and I gyve you holi writeG to techen you,” that thourgh suffraunceG and coumfort of hooli write we schal han hoppe in hym that seith, “AffeithG in me, for I have overcomen the world.”N And oure swete Fader of heven that wistG and seeth alle thinge beforun it where maad, and seeth and understondith and seeth the tribulaciounsT that holi chirche shulde suffre in this deedly liyf, and ordeyned hem with the SoneT and the Hooli Gost, thre persones in oG God almyghti, and schewed hem thorugh Jhesu his Sone and thorugh his mildenesse overecame hem.N

And he to his servantT Seint Joon ewangelist that maad this book that is clepidG Apocalips, that is to seie shewynge in goost,G he sent to hym bi his aungele for that he shulden tellen that God sent to hym holi chirche, and that is to witeG of this world to the endyng and to the tyme onG Anticrist, for the tribulaciouns schulen be so greet that alle tho that schulen be dampnedG N schulen be chaungid,G T and it shewed hym the grete goodesG that itG shulde reseyve in this lyf and the grete medisG that it shulde reseyve in the other world whanne scheG shal be joynede to hire spouse Jhesu Crist in blisse. For rightG as the adversitees asilenG T us bothe on the one halfG and that other, right so arisenN the goodes of grace and of glorie.

Werfore this book omonge other bookys of the new lawe is clepid prophecie, for that Seynt Joon saw it in gostliG sightis, the priveteesG of Jhesu Crist and of holi chirche, and a gret part ben comen and shulen comen. But for Seynt Joon saw it in gost,G holi chirch distinctithG it in thre maner sightis.N Goode is to understonde how he saugh it in gost. For a sighte is goostly whane we seen it, in slepe either wakynge,T semblant ofG eny thinge that other bodili thingis ben bitokened by, as Pharo saugh in Egipt in slep, as it tellith in Genisis. And [fol. 203v] as Moises saugh waking a grene busche brennyng and brent not, as is writun in Exodi. Thridde manere of sightis so is clepid intellectus. That is, whan the gost lightith the understondynge of the soule and makith to seen with spiritual eiye the vertuez and the privetés of God, as miche as his wille is to shewe hym, as Seint Poule was rawyschideG into the thride hevene and saugh the privetés of God that it fallithG no man to syne.G

And Seynt Joon saugh on this maner not oneli the figuris, but he understodeT what it was to menen,G N and wrot it in a yleG of the see that men clepenG Patmos. Thider a cruel emperoure DomicieG hadde flemedG hym, for Goddis wordis that he prechid to the folk. And for that he bare witnessyng of Jhesu Crist, and that was on enchesounG for that he shulde write this book. For as myche and as longe as he was flemed, ther wexen many manere vices and of heresies in holi chirches of AsieG N that he had to kepe undir God. And specially the mater of this book drawith to the chirches of Asie and comounli of alle holi chirche, namly that it suffre in this lyf and that it shal resceyve in the tother. His entent is to amonestenG into paciens, for though alle the tribulaciouns or anguysches be stronge to suffre sumtyme, the mede therfor is endeles.

His writynge is on thisT manere. On the frist, he settith a litille prolog. There he settith the name of the booke whan he seith, “the Apocalips,”T and how the sight is shewed hym bi the aungele. And aftir he blisseth alle that it redith and herith the wordis of the prophecie, and gretith the seven chirchis of Asie, and shewith oure swet Lord Jhesu Crist hou he shal come to the jugement, and how thei that there ben shulen seen hym peynedG and pleynenG hem on alle ertheli men, and after he shewith that he is gynnynge and endynge that is and was and is to comen almyghti. And after this he tellith his talle wheder of he makith this book that is departid onG sevene sightis,T so that ech man may bi hymsilf understonden and tellen.T

div.note: wilne pitousli lyven, wish to live devoutly

div.head: Chapter 1
div.ab: [fol. 204r] [1] ApocalipsG T of Jhesu Crist which GodT gaf to hym to make open to hise servauntis, whiche thingis it bihoveth to be maadT soone. And he signyfiede sendynge bi his aungel to his servaunt Joon, [2] which bar witnessynge to the word of God and witnessing of Jesu Crist in these thingis whatever thingis he say.G [3] Blessid is he that redith and he that herith the wordis of this prophecie and kepith tho thingis that ben writun in it, for the tyme is nygh.

[4] Joon to sevene chirchis that ben in Asie: grace and pees to you. Of hym that is and that was and that is to comynge, and of the sevene spiritisN that ben in the sight of his trone, [5] and of Jhesu Crist, that is a feithful witnesse, the firste bigetunG of deed men, and prince of kingis of the erthe whiche lovyde us and wasshide us fro oure synnes in his blood, [6] and made us a kyngdom and prestis to God and to his Fadir, to hym be glorie and empire, into worldis of worldis, Amen.
[7] Lo, he cometh with clowdis, and ech iyeG shal se hym, and thei that prickidenG hym and alle the kynredisG of the erthe shulen biweileG hemsilf on hym, yheG Amen.
[8] “Y am alfa and oo,G the bigynnyng and the ende,” seith the Lord God, “that is and that was, and that is to comynge, almyghti.”T

[9] I, Joon, youre brother and partener in tribulacioun and kingdom and pacience in Crist Jhesu, was in an yleG that is clepid Pathmos, for the word of God and for the witnessing of Jhesu. [10] Y was in spirit in the Lordis dai and Y herde bihynde me a grete vois as of a trumpeG [11] seiynge to me, “Write thou in a book that thing that thou seest and sende to the sevene chirchis that ben in Asie: to Efesus,G to SmirmaG and to PergamusG and to TiatiraG and to Sardis and to Philadelfia and to Loadicia.”T

The undoingeG of Seynt Joon bitokeneth prelatisG of holi chirche that undirstondith the vois of the Gospels and the thretyngis of the jugement that is bitokened bi the trumpe andT amonestith hemG that they do in werk alle that thei seen in hooly writ and teche othere thorugh goode ensaumple to do wele.

[12] And Y turnede that Y shulde se the vois that spak with me, and Y turnede and Y sayG sevene candilstikis of gold. [13] And in the myddil of the sevene goldun candilstickis, oon lyk to the sone of man clothid with a long garment and gird at the tetisG with a goldun gyrdil. [14] And the heedG of hym and his heerisG weren whyte as whyte wolleG and as snow, and the iyen of hym as flawme of fier, [15] and hise feet lyk to latouneG as in a brennynge chymeney, and the vois of hym as the vois of many watris. [16] And he hadde in his right hond sevene sterris,G and a swerd sharp on ever either sydeG wente out of his mouth, and his face as the sunne schyneth in his vertu.G T

The undoyngeG of this.T By the sevene candilstikis that Seynt Joon saugh bytokeneth hooly chyrche that is lyghtid of the sevene graces of the Hooly Goost.N That he saugh oon that was lyk the maydenesse soneN bytokeneth the bileeveG of the Resureccioun. Though alle that the fleissche of Jhesu Crist wer erG the Resureccionne, it is now another maner, for it is glorified. By the garnement that he was claadT ynne righte doune to the erthe is bitokened chastité of fleisshe. By the gyrdil that he was gird with is bytokenede chastitee of herte, by his heede the goode prelatis of hooly chirche. By the heere, the men of relygioune that schulen ben whiyte thorugh hoolynesse and of goode liyf. Als the wolle is whiyte, for they helpen the othereT thorugh goode ensaumple and ben whiyte as snow, for they quenchen the brennynge of vyresG andT [fol. 204v] vices and of synne thurgh vertu and thurgh penaunce. Bi the eyen ben bitokened the wise menT of holi chirche that lighten the othere thurgh techynge and techen hem thourgh goode exsamples of goode werkys that thai doun. Bi the feet ben bitokenede the symple folk of holi chirche that ben in the ovenes mouthe of Godis wirchyngeG T and thurgh that thei amende hem of syne. Bi his vois is bitokened the prechynge of holi chirche that is clene of syne as water of the cold wele. Bi the seven sterris ben bitokened the prelatis that owen to lyghten the lewdeG puple of goode leveyngG T that ben in derknessis of unkunnynge.G That the sterris were in his right honde bitokeneth the gud prechours. By the swerde that kittithG T on boith half bitokeneth Goddis word that on halfT departithG the soule fro his desire and on the other half departith the flesche fro hys delites. Bi his face bitokeneth hem that doun penaunce bi thei schynen as the sunne to geven light of goode ensaumples to other, boothen gude and yvele.T

[17] And as I hadde seen this, I fel to the erthe as deed. And he laide his right honde overe me and seid to me, “NylG thu dreden.T I am the frist and the last, [18] and I am alyve and was deed and now I lyve forevermore and have the keies of helle and of deith.T

[19] “Writ ther than that thu hast seen and tho thinges that now ben present and tho that motenG comen afterwarde. [20] The seven sterris that thu hast seen in my right honde ben sevenn prelatisN of holi chirche and seven candilstikis ben seven chirchis of Asie.”T

That Seynt Joon whann he hadde seen felle to the Lordis fetteG bitokeneth holi prelatis that gyven hem to ryt bileveG and understonden hem in Goddis worde and gyven that entent to conseile men after Goddis lawe.N T That he is as he were deed bitokeneth hem that forsakith the blesseG of this world. That the Lord sette his right honde on hym bitokeneth that the Lord gyveth to such prelatis strengthe and myghte to suffre persecuciouns. And that he seith he hath the keies of deeth and of helle bitokeneth that he makith hem so hardi that thai ne doutG devel ne tirant agen the wille of God.

div.head: Chapter 2
div.ab: [fol. 205r] [1] After that comaundithT oure Lord to Seynt Joon that he schulde writ to the bischop of the chirche of Effesie,N for the synnes of the puple.T “This saith he that hast the sevene sterris in his right hond amyddisG the sevene golden candelstikis: [2] I woteG thi werkis, thi travelle,G thi pacience, and that thou maist not suffren the wicked, and how thu hast asayedeG and atayntG of falsnesse hem that maken hem apostelis and ben not. [3] I wot the adversitees that thu hast suffrede for me.

[4] “But o thyngT there is, that thu hast forsake the charité that thu haddist at the bigynyng. [5] Therfor bythenke thou what thou art and do penance and the werkis that thu didist first.T ButG thou do,T I schal come soone and remove thi candilstikeT out of his stede,G but if thu do penance. [6] But this hast thou, for thou hast hatide the werkis of NicholaitisG that Y hate.
[7] “That han erisG to here,G here what the Holi Gost seith to chirchis. To hem that overcometh, I schal gyve meteG of the tree of liyf that is in paradis of my God.”

That oure Lord bad that he shulde write to the bischop of Effesy for the synne of the folk bitokeneth that oure Lord schal axenG of the prelatis the soulis of sugetis.G That he seith, “I wot thi werkis and thi travele and of his pacience,” amonestith us that we tak good exaumple. That he undirnymethG hem, that thai han lorneG ther charité that thai hadden biforen, bitokeneth that the postel Seynt Poule seith, “Though I have as myche strengthe that I may stireG hilles fro o stede to another and gyve my bodi to brenne, and I have not charité, al is not worthi to me.”N That he thretith that he shal remove his candilstike but if thai do penaunce, that is to seie but if thei amende hem, he schall binemenG hem the graces that thai han. That he seith, “He that hath eres to heren, here,” bitokeneth that oure Lord seith in the gospelle, “That Y seie to oon, I seie to alle.”N That he bihotithG hem that thai shulen eten of the tre of lyf bitokeneth that he shalle gyven hem the frute of the cros in his Fader blis.

[8] “To the chirche of SmyrmaN write this, seith he that is gynnynge and endynge, was deed and lyveth. [9] I wote thi tribulacioun and thi povert, but thu art riche, and art blasfemed of hem that seienG that thei ben Jewis and ben not, but thei ben the synagoge of Sathanas.G [10] Drede thu nothing of these thingis whiche thu schalt suffre,T but have thu no drede, for the devel schal do dounG summe of you into prysoun to asayenG you and [fol. 205v] ten dayes ye shulen han tribulaciouns. Be trewe ryt to the deeth. I shal give a crowne of lyf, [11] and he that overcomethT schal han no drede of the seconde deeth.”

By the asaute of fals menN bitokeneth the asaute of coveitise.G By the tribulaciounT of the fende,G that bitokeneth the asaute of pride and thurgh tribulacioun and temptacioun of the flesch. To hem that wille suffre povert and overcome coveitise, oure LordT bihotithG hem richessis, and he that thurgh lownesseG overcome prid, oure Lord bihotith hem coroun of lyf, and to hem that thurgh abstinence overcometh tribulacioun, oure Lord bihotith hem esseG in the other lif, and in that heT setith hymself exsaumple that he seith, “I was deed and I lyve.”

[12] “To the bischop of the chirche of Pergame,N write thu thes thinges, seith he that hath the swerde sharpe on bothe half.G [13] I wot wele that ye wonethG T in the power of Satanas and thu holdist my nameT and denyest not my feith, and in tho dayes was AntifasG N my feithful witnesse that was slayn at youG where Satanas dwellith.T In as moche ye have forsake my lawe.T

[14] “But o thingeT there is among you, that holdith the techyng of Balam, that taught the kyng BalacG to do the childer of Israel synnen, that one corumpideG the other thurgh yvel ensaumple of leccherie and to eten of theT sacrificis of ydolisN [15] and to holden the techyngT of Nicholaitis. [16] Therfor do ye penaunce, and but ye doun,G I shalle come and fighten witG the yvele doandeG wit the swerde of my mowth.
[17] “And to hymT that overcometh I schalt gyven hym manna hydG , and I shal gyven hym an harde ston, and in the hard stoun a new name shal be writtunN no man wot what but he that reseveth it.”

Here is bitokened thre maner of synnes that ben in many that han resayved the bileveG and holden it not. Ech fordoithG othere thurgh evel counceyle that thai han goven othere, thurgh exsaumple of lecherie, the thredG thurgh exsaumple of glotonye. To hem that thurgh sobirnesseT overcometh glotonye, oure Lord bihotith hem the swete blisse of heven, and that is manna.T To hym that thurgh chastité colithG his flesch, he bihotith hym stedfastnesse of flesch and of light, and that is the hard stooun that is bricteG and clere. To hem that with strengthe bridilenG ther tunge fro yvel speche, oure Lord byhotith hem the glorie of God to herienG hym wit tunge, and his newe name writen in the stooun. That he seith he shalle come sone and shalle fighten with the evele doers with the swerd of veniaunceG T bitokeneth that in litil tyme he [fol. 206r] departith the bodi fro the soule thurgh boodili deeth, and that is the scharpe of the swerde on that on half. And at the day of jugementT he shale depart the bodi and the soule fro the blissed compani of his chosene and out of his blisse, and that is the scharpe of the swerde on that other half.

[18] “To the bischop of the chirche of Tiatire,N write that is seide bi thisG that hath the eyen as the flawme of fier and the fete that semeden as cledes.G N [19] I wot thi werkis and thi dedis and thi charité,T and how thou art go thurgh amendement.

[20] “But o thingeT it is, that thou suffrist a womman Jezabelle that seith sche is a prophetesse,N that sterithG T my servantis to lecherie and to ete of the sacrificis of ydols. [21] And I have goven hem space to repenten hem, and thei wil not. [22] And therfor I shalle leyn hir in bedde and hem that han felawschiped with hir, that thei shulen be in gret tribulacioun but thei amenden hem. [23] And hir schildren I schal sleen.G And witenG wele shulen alle chirchis that I secheG the renesG and the hertis and yeldeG mede after that ye serven.

[24] “To you I seie that ben not of the develis techynge,N T that I charge yow no more. [25] But the techyng that yee han,T holdith it to the deeth.T [26] And he that overcometh shal han power over the misbilevande,G N and [28] after I schalle given hym the dai sterre.”G T T

Bi Jazabelle ben understonden the maister heretikis that lyven after the wille of hir flesch and techen agen the gospel. Suche shulden not Cristen men suffre among hem. After that thei be lastendeG in hir folie. That oure Lord seith that he hath leide hir in a bede bitokeneth hem that lynG longe in hir synnes and wil not amenden hem, and lettithT hym gon at herG wille and gyven hem to ertheli thingis. That he seith that he schal sechen the hertes and the renes bitokeneth that he shal taken veniance of hem that lyven in evel lif, and to the godde that han poustéG of hir lyvesT and holden hem underfote. He bihoteth power to governe othere, and to hem that lighten othere thurgh goode techynge bihotith hem the brightnesse of the Resurreccioun of Jhesu, that is the day sterre.
