div.head: Chapter 3
div.ab: [1] “And to the aungele of the chircheT of Sardis, write thu that isT that he seith that hath seven sterris.T I wot wel thi werkis, for that men seyn thu art deed and thou lyvest.T [fol. 206v] [2] Therfor wake and confermeG hem that ben dyeande,G T that I fynde not youre werkis foule biforn God. [3] And therfor bithenke yee hou ye have hardeG and kepe it and do penaunce. And if that thou wolt not, I shal come to thee as a theefN whanne thou shalt witen no word.N

[4] “But a fewe ther ben in youre chirche that han not defoulid ther clothinge,T and thai shul go with me in aubis.G For thai ben worthi [5] that overcometh, so he shal be clade in whiyt clothingeN and I shal not putten out his name of the book of lyf, and I shal preisen hem biforn my Fadir and his aungels.”T

Bi that, that thei have the name of goode lyf and ben dead,N bitokeneth the ypocritis that han werkis of holynesse and entent of yvel. He hem thretith that hoG shalle come as a theef and binymen hem her goodis that thai have and sleen hem thurgh the deith that ever shal laste, but ifG thei waken in her werkis thurgh right undirstondynge. Thei that han not her bodiesT filde with lecherie ne werkis of evel entent, that thurgh yvel wil, her bodies shulen be with Jhesu Crist and her werkis fayre in the felawschipe of Jhesu Crist. And her names shulen not be doun outG T of the booke of lyf that is her loesG of good and mede everlastende as the werkis of ypocritis shulen be doun awey, for thei ben likned to the false theves that destroyen men.T

[7] “And to the aungele of the chirche of Filadelfie, write thou thes thingis, seith the holi and trewe that hath the keiye of David, the whiche openeth and no man closith; he closith and no man openeth. [8] I wot thi werkis, and lo, I gaf bifor thee a dore opened, the whiche no man mai close. For thu hast a litel vertu and hast kept my word and denyedist not my name. [9] Lo, I shal gyve to thee of the synagoge of Sathanas, the whiche seyne hem to ben Jewes and ben not, but lien. Lo, I schal maken hem that thai come and worschepe biforn thi feet, and thei shal wite for I lovede thee, [10] for thu keptist the word of my pacience. And I shal kepe thee fro the oureG of temptacioun that is to comen into alle the world to tempten men dwellende in erthe.

[11] “Lo, I come soone. Holde that thu hast that no man take thi coroune.G [12] And hym [fol. 207r] that shal overcome I shal make a piler in the temple of my God, and he shal no more go out, and I shal write on hym the name of my God and the name of the cité of my God, of new Jerusalem that cometh doun fro heven of my God, and my newe name.”T T

That oure Lord bihotith the dore open for that he hath a litil vertue and hath kepte the feith bitokeneth that oure Lord opened heven and holi write to hem that han litil kunnyngeG and kepen his comaundement. That heT hotithG that he shal doG come the folk to fallen to his feet bitokeneth that is seid in holi writ, “Lo, I schal make thine ennemys faleG bifore thi feet.”N That he shal kepen hem fro the grete temptacioun bitokeneth that at the comynge of Anticrist, folk shalen turnen to the bileveG and not chaunge for no miracle that he doith, ne for no turment. That he bihotith and to hym that overcometh to maken hym a piler bitokeneth hem that ben aparayledG to suffre turment for the right bileve of holi chirche to holden it up. Hem shalle not oure Lord suffre to gon outeG thorough synne. That he seith he schal write the thre namesT bitokeneth the thre glories that thei shulen han. The on is the knowynge of God, the othere is the felawschip of aungels, the thredde the sight of Jhesu,T God and man.

[14] “And to the aungele of the chirche of Loadice, writ thou these thinges, seith Amen that is verili the feithfulle witnesse and trewe, the whiche is the bigynnynge of Goddis creature.G [15] I wott thi werkis, for nether thou art colde, nether thou art hote. I wolde that thou were coold ether hoot. [16] But for thou art leweG and neither cold neither hote, I schal bigyne for to cast thee out of my mouthe. [17] For thou seist that ‘I am riche and ful of goodis and I have no nede of no man,’T and thou woost not for thou art a wrecche and wreccheful, and thu art pore and blynde and nakid. [18] I counsele thee for to bieG of me gold firid and prevedG that thou be maad riche and be clothid with whiyte clothis that the confusiounG of thi nakidnesse appere not. And anoynte thyn iyen with a colerie,G that is medicyne for iyen gaderid of dyverse eerbisG that thou see.T

[19] “Whom I love, I reprove and chastise.T Therfor sueG or love and do penaunce. [20] Lo, I stonde at the dore and knoke. If any man schal here my vois and opene the gate, I schal entre to him and soupeG [fol. 207v] with hym and he with me.
[21] “I shal gyven to hym that shal overcome to sitten with meT in my trone, as IT overcam and satt with my Fader in his trone. [22] He that hath eris, here what the spirit shal seyn to chirchis.”T

Bi hym that is cold is bitokened he that kanG not of the beleve. Bi the hote is bitokened hem that han right feith in werkis of charitee. Bi the deef heedG T bitokeneth hem that have bileve withoute werk. The castyngT out at the mouthe bitokeneth that thei ben put out of the coumpanye of holy. That he seith he bigynneth to casten hym oute bitokeneth that oure Lord gyveth hem space to amende hem.T That he seith that thai ben riche and have no misterG of noght bitokeneth that fals Cristen men ben wersG than tho that ben oute of the lawe, that ben Jewis and SarasenesG that ben mysbylevende men for defauteG of techynge.N Bi the gold fired is bitokened penaunce. Bi the whiyt clothinge is bitokened clennesse of fleisch. Bi the onementisG N is bitokenede werkis of merci. That he stant at the dore and knokkythT bitokeneth that the grace of God is ever redi to entren to the synner, and amonestith hym thorough prechynge and thorough tribulacioun. To openne the gate is bitokened levynge of seineG forevere.T And thanne oureT Lord entreth into hym whan he taketh to wilneG his werkis. He soupith with oure Lord whan he hath wil to do wel and in that endith his lyf. That bihotith that he shal be with hym in his troone bitokeneth that he shal be glorified in fleisch as the sunne is. There he shal be at the jugement; ther the poure shulen juge othere. That he seith, “He that hath eres to heren, here that the gost seithT to chirchis” bitokeneth that oure Lord seith in the gospel, “That I seie to on, I saie to alle.”N

div.note: taketh to wilne, gains a desire for

div.head: Chapter 4
div.ab: [1] And after saw Seynt Joon a doreT open of hevene and the vois that he herde first as the voice of a trumpe seide to hym, “Cum up hidir and I shal shewe thee the thingis that ben to comen sone after this.”T [2] And as soone he was ravesched up to heven and saugh [fol. 208r] a segeG sette in heven, and on the sege he saugh a sitter. [3] And the Lord that saat semede as it were to the sight of jasper and sardines.G T

That Seynt Joon saugh the dore open of hevene bitokeneth that the goode prelat that hath the undirstondynge of holi writ and understondith the olde lawe monestith hym to bataile agen vices and synnes, and that is the frist voice as it were of a trumpe. The stiyynge upG bitokeneth the heeghnesse of goode lif after the techyng of the gospelle. The schewynge of thingis that shulden comen bitokeneth that thei shul smele the swetnesse of the lif that ever shal lasten. That he was spiredG in gost bitokeneth that he that hath the grace of God doith hymself out of the ydel thoughtis of ertheli thingis. That he saugh the sege sette in hevene bitokeneth that he seteth his thoughtis into juggement. Bi the sege is bitokened the holyG that restith in God. Bi the colour of the stoune bitokeneth the two kyndisG of God almighti: the godhede and the manhede. And bi the hardnesse of the stoon bitokeneth that he shal be harde agen his ennemys. And bi the coluorrs that ben plesaunt to mannes sight bitokeneth that he shal love ableG T to his frendis. And bi the two colurrs that ben in the reyneboweN bitokeneth two juggementis in whiche God saveth hise.G N The friste was thorough Noes flod. The other shal be at endynge of this world thurgh fier. EitherG T it bitokeneth that alle that han receyved Cristendam and dien in synne shulen comen at the juggement biforn Jhesu Crist and sweren ofG his blodT that he shede for hem.

[4] AbouteG the sege ben foure and twenté segis, and on the foure and twenté segis sitten foure and twenté greeteG or oldeT covered in whit clothinge and hadden on her hedes crownesse of gold. [5] And out of the trone cam lightynge and thundrynge,T and sevene laumpis brennende ben biforunG the trone that ben the sevene spiritis of God. [6] And biforun the sege alsT a seeG of glas that semed as it were cristalle.

Bi the foure and twenti grete ben bitokened the twelve patriarkis and prophetis and the twelve apostlis and the holi [fol. 208v] seyntisN that shul sitte at the juggement to jugen the other. The whiyt clothinge bitokened that her bodies ben glorified. The crounes of gold bitokenen the victorie that thai have in werkis of charité. Bi lightynge that the spirit doith is bitokened the miraclis that God diedeG for hem to lighten mennes hertis to the bileve. Bi the voisisN is bitokened predicaciouns,G T the thundre the thretyng of oure Lord that he makith thorough the tribulaciouns that he sendith biforun the juggement. Bi the seven laumpis bitokeneth the seven graces of the Holi Gost that lighten and spirenG the hertis that God restith in. Bi the cristalle that wexethG hard in the water as stooun bitokeneth the Cristen men that ben confermed thoroughT tribulaciounT to the right bileve and in goode lyf.

In myddis the sege and abouten ben foure bestes ful of eyen bihynde and biforun. [7] The firste beste semede a leounG and the other an oxe, and the thride hadde a face as a man. The ferthe was lecheG to an egle. [8] And eche of thes foure hadde sixe wynges and aboute and withinnen weren ful of eyen, and withstyntenG not to seyne,T “Holi, holi, Lord God almighti,T that art and were and shalt come.”

Bi these foure bestes ben bitokened the foure gospelerisG that speken of the manhede of Jhesu Crist and of his godhede and of his deeth and of his Resurreccioun.T For the lioun is dedeG whan he is borun, and the thridde day he cometh to lif thurghT the cry of his fadir.N And oure Lord that died on the roodeG for us, on the thridde day he cometh to lyf thurgh the cry of his Fader. And oure Lord that died on the roode for us, on the thridde dai roos fro deeth to lyve. And bi the oxe is bitokened Seynt Luke, for he spekith specialyG of the sacrifice that was maad of Jhesu Crist on the roode for oure synnes. For in the olde lawe,N it was comaundede to make sacrifice of oxen for synnes of the folk. Bi liknesse of man is bitokened Seint Mathew, for specialli he spak of the manhede of Crist. Bi the egle is bitokened Seint Joon, for he spak heighest of the Passioun of Jhesu Crist. For the egle is a bredG that heighest may fleenG [fol. 209r] and clerest is of sight.N Bi the two wyngis biforun is bitokened meknesse withyne in hert and charité.T Bi the wyngis amydde, clennesse of hert and chastité of flesche. Bi the two wenges above, the love of God and his even Cristen.G That thai ben fulle of eyen biforun and bihynde bitokeneth the gospelleris that serchen the synnes that man hath doun and to fleG hem that ben to comen. That thai weren ful of yyen withynnen and withouten bitokeneth that the apostle seith that we shulden be “bisiG to do wel not oneli bifor God but also biforne the folk.”N That thai styntyn not to sey, “Holy, holy, holy” bitokeneth that thei that holden the ruele ofT the gospelis shulen everemore in alle her werkis heryenG the Trynité and yeldenG worschipe to God, for he maad us and boughte us agen and saved us, and for the godisG that he doith us now and shal doun us in that other lif. Bi the leoun bitokeneth hem that ben stronge and hardi to suffren harmes for the loveT of holi chirche. Bi the oxe ben bitokened hiseG that ben scharpe in penaunce. Bi the man bitokeneth the men that ben light and mylde to drawen hem to goode. By the egle ben bitokenede men of religion that ben in good lyfe or in thought of God or in other manere for these foure figuris that ben four vertues. Bi the leoun, strengthe. Bi the oxe, temperanceT and mesure.G Bi the man, rightfulnesse.G Bi the egle, quentise.G

[9] And as the foure bestis yelden grace and worschipe and blissynge to the Lord that sat on the trone and lyveth withouten ende, [10] the foure and twenti greet fellen doun biforen the trone and honoureden hym and leiden ther crownesT biforn the trone and seiden, [11] “Oure Lord God, thu art worthi to resceyven blissynge and worschipe and vertue, for thu madist alle thing and bi thi wille alle thinge is maad.”

That the foure and twenti greete fellen biforn the trone bitokeneth that the holi men thenken on the juggement. That thai leiden her crounes biforn the trone bitokeneth that thai beknowenG that the maistrye that thai han over the fendeT is his and not her,G fore he overecame hym with his Passion. That thei seyn that he is worthi to resceiven worschipe and vertu and honour bitokeneth that thai gladidenG of the glorie of Resureccioun and the honour of the Assencioun,G [fol. 209v] vertu of gret myght that he hath with his Fadir and shal han at the juggement.

note.gloss: Gospel writers (Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John)

div.head: Chapter 5
div.ab: [1] Seynt Joon sawe at the right halfG of the Lord on the trone a booke writen withouten and withynne sealid with seven claspis. [2] And I saw an aungeleT prechen with loude cry, “Who is worthi to undo the book and unbynden the claspis?” [3] And non myghte oondo the book to loken theron in hevene ne erthe ne undir erthe. [4] And he wepte, for non was worthi to undon this book. [5] And on of the grete saide to hym, “Ne wepe thou. Lo, the leon of the kynde of JudaG that is roote of DavithN hath overcomeT to opene the booke and undo the claspis.”

Bi the right half of the Lord is bitokened Goddis Sone. Bi the trone that he settith upon is bitokened the flesch that he tok of the Vergyn Marie, thereG the godhede restith. Bi the book is bitokened the saveour to bien man agen.G N The writynge withinne bitokeneth the olde lawe that techith derkly with figuris. Bi the writyng without bitokenethT that techith openli. The seven claspis ben bitokened the seven sacramentis of holi chirche or the seven giftis of the Holi Gost.N Bi the stronge aungel is bitokened the olde fadres of the old lawe.T Bi the prechynge of grete vois is bitokened the grete desire of the comynge of oure saveoure. That ther was non in heven to undo it, that is seide biG the aungele. Ne in erthe, that is seide bi the mann. Ne undir erthe, that is seide bi the soule out of the bodi. Bi the wepynge of Seint Joon, that is bitokened the same thing that is. Bi the cry of the stronge aungele, the gret desire that the olde hadden to the bileve. Bi oon of the olde, eche of the prophetis that coumfortith of the old lawe and bihighteG hem that Goddis Sone wold come and take flesch and blod to delivere hem and hidden his godhede thurgh the manhede, that the proude might not know hym, as the lion doith awey his traceG with his tayle whan he fleeth bi the mownteynes that he be not founden. And as the lion slepith and hath his eyen opyne, so died he on the roode as to the flesch and lyved as to the godhed.N

[6] And I sawe, seith Seynt Joon, amyddis the trone and myddis the foure [fol. 210r] and twenti grete, a LombG stondden as it were slayn, and seven hornes and seven eyen that ben the seven spirittis of God and he sente into alle londis. [7] And the Lomb cam and took the book of the right half of hym that sat on the trone. [8] And as he hadde opened the book, the foure bestis and the foure and twenti grete fellen bifore the Lomb. Alle hadden harpis and fithelisG of gold ful of swete smele,N tho ben the preyeris of seyntis,T [9] and sungenN and seyden, “Lord God, thou art worthi to opene the book and undo the claspis, for thou were slayn and thou boughtist agen with thi blood to God of alle kyndis and tungis and folkis and naciouns, [10] and thou hast made us a rengneG to oure God and prestis, and we shulen regne on erthe.”

That the Lomb took the book on the right half of the Lord bitokeneth Goddis Sone, bi the right half that he mariedG hym clen to flesch withouten synne. That is bitokened bi the Lomb that tok the batel for us agen the fende in myledenes,G and bi the wisdam that is bitokened bi the book. That the Lomb stode as he were deed and sat bitokeneth that he suffreth passioun in his manhede and in his godhede was holeG as to hymself, outher he is deede in erthe in his lymesG thorough tribulaciouns and in blisse he is holliche.G That hade seven hornes that ben upward and seven eyen that ben seven spiritis of God sent into alle londis bitokened the seven giftis of the Holi Goost that Jhesu Crist hade, as YsayeG saith,N and the giftis to his asaute of her ennemys that came fro high thureG pride and tribulaciouns of tirantis of the world and thurgh temptaciouns binethenG as the asaughtis of coveitiseG and of flesly likyngis and of eretikis. The openynge of the book bitokeneth the comynge of Jhesu Crist thurgh his werkis in erthe. The foure bestis bitokeneth the foure prechours of the Gospels on foure halfG of the world. The foure and twenti grete bitokenen hem that shul sitten with Jhesu Crist at the juggement to jugen hise. That thei fellen biforn the Lomb bitokeneth that the holi menT lowen hemG whan thai remembre hem of that Jhesu Crist suffred that was withouten synne. That thei han herpis bitokeneth hem [fol. 210v] that slowenG her flesche wiseely on the crosse of penaunce, as the cordeG is atempreG sett in the tree of the harpe to gyve godde soon.G That thei hadden the violisG N of gold ful of swete odoures bitokenethT that thei hadde the hertis fully of gladnesse and michilG in the affeccioun of charité that thai spreden out to loven her enemyes and to biddenG for hem. That thai songen new songis bitokeneth the heryyngG that thai maad to Jhesu Crist and gladidenG that he is worthi to undo the book. For he oneli was man withoute eche maner of synne and boughte us with his preciouse blod. And whanne the kyngdame of his fadir, thar we shul regne with joyeT and blisse withouten eny ende.T

[11] And I sawe and herde a voise of many aungels about his trone, and the foure and twenti grete and the foure bestisT [12] that seiden with gret vois, “The Lomb that is slayn is worthi to resceyven vertu,T wisdam, and strengthe, honour,T glorie, and blisinge.” [13] And alle creaturis hym honour. [14] And the bestis seiden, “Amen.” And the foure and twenti gret fellen in her faces and worschipeden hym that lyveth withouten ende.

The vois of many thousynde aungelis bitokeneth the joye that the aungelisT in heven and the holi men in holi chirche of mankynde and of alle the graces that God gyveth to holi chirche. Oweth manG yelde worschipe to Jhesu Crist thoroughT whos meryt that it is, and that is confermyngeG of the foure bestis that seiden, “Amen.”

div.note: kynde of Juda, tribe of Judah
bien man agen, ransom mankind (buy mankind again)

div.head: Chapter 6
div.ab: [1] And I saugh that the Lomb openede oon of the sevenne claspis, and I herde that on of the foure bestis seide to me as it wer a vois of thundris, “Cum see.” [2] And I saw a whiyt hors comen out, and he that sat theronne hadde a bowe, and a coroune was goven to hym. And he came out overcomende to overcomen.G

Bi the whiyt hors is bitokened holi chirche that is clene of synne thurgh the baptem thurgh the deeth of Jhesu Crist. He that sat theronne bitokeneth Goddis Soone. Bi the bowe is bitokened holi writ that thretith the yvel doeres thorough jugement. Bi the coroune that is goven hym bitokeneth the SaresynesG that ben turnedG to hym. That he went out overcomende to overcome bitokeneth that he shal torneG hisG thurgh hem that he schal senden agenG the endynge of the world.

[3] And as he openede the othere claspe, I herde that other best that seide to me, “Come see.” [4] And I saugh a reede hors comynge out, and to hym that satt there uponT is goven to take pees fro the erthe and eche slowenG othere. And a gret [fol. 211r] swerde was goven to hym.

Bi this reed hors is bitokened the tirauntis that schedden the blud of martiris. And he that sat theron bitokeneth the devel to whom was goven power to grevenG al holi chirche. The greet swerde bitokeneth ertheli might.T

[5] And as he opened the thridde seal, I sawe the thride beste that seid to me, “Come see.” And I saugh a blak hors comende out, and he that sat therone hadde a balaunceT in his honde. [6] And I herd as it were a woisG amyddis the foure bestis that seide, “Two bilibresG of wheteT for a peny and thre bilibrisT of barliT for a peny. Wyn and oyle do no harme.”

Bi the blac hors is bitokened eretikis in whiche the devel regneth. Bi the balaunceT is bitokened discrecionG that thei seyen that thei han holi writ. But the prechynge of the gospelle defendith hem that thai do no harme to hem that oure Lord boughte with his blood, and that is he that seith, “Two mesuris of whete for a peny.” Bi the whete ben bitokened holi men in holi chirche to maken two mesuresT for two manereT men, Jewis and Sarisynes, ether for these two vertues that thai han stedfast bileve and goode werkis.T Bi the barli bitokeneth the symple folk that ben savede thurgh the bileve of the holi Trinité. Bi the penyT wherof thei ben boughte is bitokened Jhesu Cristis blod. And bi the wyn and oyle ben bitokened the olde lawe and the new.

[7] And as he openedT the ferthe seal, I harde the vois of the ferthe best that seide to me, “Come see.” [8] And thane I saugh a dunG hors comende oute, and he that saat on hymT was clepith Deith,G and helle folewide. And hym was goven myght on the four partis of erthe to sleen with swerde and with hunger and of the deeth of the bestis of erthe.N

Bi the dun hors ben bitokened ypocritis and the devel that wonnethG in hem that is Deeth. Thurgh hem the devel may lightliG disceyve the folk, for that he is privey,G the more he may greven.G For the helle folowith hym is bitokened that the ypocritis ben coveitouse and mouneG not be fildeG in here coveitise. That hym is goven power on the foure halfG of the erthe bitokeneth that he hath lordschipe of the Jewes and of the Sarasynes, of eretikis and of false Cristen men. The swerd that he sleeth with bitokeneth ertheli myght that thei slen with false jugis.T Hungir bitokeneth defaute of techynge. The Deeth bitokened false lore.G The bestes of the erthe bitokeneth glotonye and leccherie.

[9] And as he opened the fift seal, he saugh undir the auterG the soulis that were sleyn [fol. 211v] for Goddis word and the witnesse that thai hadden.T [10] And thai crieden with a gret cry, “Lord God, holi and sothfast,G hou long wilt abide that thou ne wrekeG oure blod of hem that wonenG in erthe?” [11] And men gafT ech a stoleG whiyt, and it is seide to hemT that thai shulen resten hem a while, til the noumbre was fulfilled of her britherenT that ben to be slayn yit.T

Bi the auter is bitokened Jhesu Cristis flesche. That he saithG the soulis under the auter bitokened that the soulis of holiG as longe as ther bodies ben in erthe and seen Jhesu Crist glorified in flesche, and that is the whiyt stole that hym was goven. And thei crieden with grete crie that he venge hem bitokeneth the gret desire that thei han of the jugement, for the desire that thai han of the reryngeG of her bodies in whiche thei haddenG another stole and shulen ben herG aboveT the autere, that is to seie that thai shulen han ful knowyng of Jhesu Crist in his godhede and than shalle here joiye ben double, thane thai shul be glorified in bodi and soule. That men saide to them that thai rest a while til that the nombre of ther bretheren wer fulfillid bitokeneth solaseG and the coumforte that thai han of her abidynge for the gret company that thai abiden to han in glorie.T

[12] And whane he hadde openede the sixte claspe, thanne I sawe that ther was a grete erthe stirynge,G T and the sune was maad blak as the sak of an hayreG and the moneG is maad as blod [13] and the sterris fellen to the erthe as it were the fruyte of the figerG that fellen with the wynde. [14] And the heven partide as a book foldenN and eche mountayne and yleT ben stiride of ther stede.G

[15] And kyngis and princis and the cheventeynesG and the riche and the stronge and alle thrallisG and free hidden hem in dichisG and in rochisG T [16] and seyn to mounteyns and to rochis, “Fallith on us and hiddith us fro the face of hym that sittith on the trone and fro the wrathe of the Lomb!T [17] For the greet day of here wraththe is comen and whoo may stande?”

The greet erthe stirynge bitokeneth the greet percecusion of Anticrist. That the sonne wexe blak bitokeneth that Jhesu Crist shal be derk to hym and to miraclis that he doith. And his membrisG that shul be than in tribulacions, that bitokeneth the harde haire.G N But he shal saven his, and that bitokeneth the blod. That the mone is blod bitokeneth that holi chirche shal be than in gret tribulaciounT overal for the tirauntis that shulen slee the goode and spillen her blode. That the sterris fallen doun bitokened hem that semeden [fol. 212r] religiouse shulen haten thanne the right bileve to saven her bodies. That the figir cast his frute with the wynde bitokeneth that holi chirche shal delyvere hir of false Cristen men for the percecucioun that thane shal ben. That heven shal departen hir as a book turnethT bitokeneth the defaute of sothefastG prechynge that thane shal be. And the mountenes and the ylesT ben stired oute of here stede bitokeneth that the good shule than be departid fro the wicke. Bi the hidynge is bitokened the grate lownesse of holiG and many maneres that thai shulen ben in thanne and the prieres that thei shulen make to fleen the wraththe of the jugement.

div.note: overcomende to overcomen, coming over to conquer
sak of an hayre, sackcloth made of animal skin (haircloth)
stiride of ther stede, moved from its place

div.head: Chapter 7
div.ab: [1] After I sawe foure aungels stonden on the foure corners of the ertheT that helden the foure wyndis of the erthe that thai blew not on the erthe ne on the see ne on the trees. [2] And I saw anothere aungele stiyendeG up fro the risyngG T and hade the mark of God lyvendeG and cried with gret vois to the foure aungels that han resceyved the power to greveG the erthe and the see and seide, [3] “Willith not to greven the erthe ne see ne trees til that we marke the servauntis of oure God in ther forhedes.”T [4] And I herde the noumbre of the markid: an hundride foure and fourti thousendeT of eche kyndeG of the sonesT of Israel.

[5] Of the kynde of Juda, twelve thousende signede.G Of the kynde of Ruben, as manye. Of the kynde of Gaad, as manye. [6] Of the kynde of Aser, as many. Of the kynde of Neptalym, as manye. [7] Of the kynde of Simeon, as manye. Of the kynde of Levy, as many. Of the kynde of Ysachar, as manye. [8] Of the kynde of Zabulon, as manye. Of the kynde of Joseph, as manye. Of the kynde of Benjamyn, as many. Of the kynde of Manasse, as manye.N T

The foure aungelis that helden the foure wyndis bitokeneth the develis that shulen distroien the prechynge and Gospelis that thei stereG not the reynesG of grace to dwellen in the herte of the synful. That the aungele went forth into the estwarde and defendith hym bitokeneth that Jhesu Crist came dounT to bynymeG the fende of his power that he myght not noyenG as myche as he wolde. In the markenge in the forhede bitokeneth that the sothfastG T Cristen man makith on hym the cros to shew that the bileve of the cros is in his herte as he is aknoweG T with his mouthe withoute shame. That [fol. 212v] he saugh the noumbre of the markide bitokeneth that alle shul be savede that han percecucioun with gud wille of herte. Thousoundis bitokeneth overcomyngis, and temptaciouns that bitokened hundrid, and soithfaste penance bitokeneth fourti, and the feithT of the Gospelis foure.N

[9] After I sawe a gret asemblé that noon myght telleG of alle manere of menN that stonden bifore the trone in sight of the Lomb, hilidG with whit stolis and palmis in her hondis,N [10] and crieden with gret vois,T “Helthe to oure Lord God that sitte on the trone and to the Lomb.” [11] And alle the aungelis stoden aboute the trone, and alle the grete and the foure bestis fellen bifore the trone in her faces and onouredenT God [12] and seiden, “Amen. Blessynge, clerté,G T wisdam, grace, and honoure, vertu and strengthe be to oure Lord withouten ende.”

The gret multitude that no man myght noumbren that that stoden biforn the trone bitokeneth hem that after that Anticrist is fordounG shulen stonden in holi chirche and after the jugement in heven. The goode Cristen men that thurgh goode lif han overcome the tribulacioun of the world, that is bitokened thurgh peyne thei shulen yelden graceG to God, for that he hath savede hem thurgh his Sone. That thai fallen biforne the trone and honoureden God bitokeneth the gret joye that aungelis shulen han of the greet compenye of holi men and wymmen in blesse wherthurghG thei shulen yelden grace to God.
[13] And oon of the grete answerde andT seide to me, “These that ben covered with whiyt stolis, what ben thai, and whennes camen thei?”
[14] And I seide to hym, “My lord, thu wost.”G T

And he seyde to me, “It ben thei that ben comen fro gret tribulacioun and han waschen ther stolis and maade hem whiyte in the blod of the Lomb. [15] And therfor thai ben biforn Goddis trone and serven hym day and nyght in his temple. And he that sitt in the trone woneth onG hemT [16] that thai shulen never han hungris ne thriste ne the sunne shal not fallen on hem ne noon hete, [17] for the Lomb that sittith amyd the trone shal coverneG N hem, and he shal leden hem to the wellis of watre of lif and shal wepynG awey eche tereT fro ther eyen.”

Bi the spekynge of the grete is bitokened holi writtT that techith us and monestith us to suffre tribulaciouns in this lif and to wasche bodi and soule thurgh schrifteG and witenG hem thurgh goode werkis in the bileve of Jhesu Criste in hope of the goodis that evere shal lasten.

div.head: Chapter 8
div.ab: [fol. 213r] [1] And as the LombT opened the seventhe claspe, silence is maad in heven as it were the space of half an our. [2] And I saugh sevene aungelis stonden biforen the face of God and hem ben goven seven trumpis.

[3] And another aungel comendeG stodde biforn the autere and hadde a censer of gold in his honde, and manye encensis ben govun to hym that he shuld gyve of the orisonesG of alle halowenG upon the autere of gold that is biforn the trone. [4] And the smok of the encensT of preieris of alle halowen wente up fro the aungeles hond biforn God. [5] And the aungele took the censer and fild it ful of the fier of the autere and sente it into the erthe. And there weren madeT thoundryngis and voicesG N and lightnyngis and grete styrynge of erthe.

Bi the silence that is maad in heven as bi the space of half an oure bitokeneth the pees that holi chirche shal have after the distreciounG of Anticrist, and after shal sooneT comen the jugement. The seven aungelis with seven trumpis bitokeneth alle the prechours in holi chirche that ben taughte thurgh the grace of God and the seven giftis of the Holi Goost. That other aungele that stode bifore the autere bitokeneth Goddis Sone in manhede. The senser of gold bitokeneth holi chirche that ensensithG the praiers of the seyntis. The smok of the encens that stiyeth up bitokeneth the compucciounG of hertis that wexith of orisones. That he fild the censer of the fier of the auter bitokeneth that he techith the hertis that han mynde of his Passioun. That he sent intoT the erthe bitokeneth that he sent his disciplis to prechen the gospel. Bi the thundir ben bitokened the thretyng that he thretith us with, the jugement that God shal make thurgh the prechours. Bi the vois, the bihest of glorie. Bi the lightynge, the miraclis. Bi the gret erthe sterynge bitokeneth the gret lownesse.G T

[6] And the seven aungelis that hadden the seven trumpis maden hem redi to syngenG in trumpe.T [7] And at the trumpynge ofT the firste aungele is maad hail with fier mengidG with blood and is sente into erthe. And the thridde part of the erthe is brent and a gret part of trees andT grene hey.G

The trumpynge of the first aungel bitokeneth the first prechynge that was maad to the Jewes that weren goven to the love of ertheli thingis. And that the hail and the fire was menged with blood bitokeneth the wicke wordis and the felonye of the Jewis whan thei spilten Jhesu Cristis blod and his halewes.G Bi the erthe that the thridde part is brent [fol. 213v] bitokeneth coveitouse men. Bi the trees, the proude men, the thridde part ben dampned. The grene heighG bitokeneth the delicesG of the world that ben goven to delites of flesche that turnen hem more to evel than good. And therfore al is brent and thane is the gret part dampned.

[8] And at the trumpynge of the secounde angele is as it were an hille brenandeT sent into the see. And the thridde part of the see is maad blod, [9] and the thridde part of the creatures that hadden soulis in the see and the thridde part of the schippis perischid.

The trumpynge of the secounde aungel bitokeneth the frist prechinge that was prechideT to the Jewes, turned afterward to the panymes.G That the brennende hilT is sente into the see bitokeneth the enwyeG that the devel hath to prouden,G the erroure to noye.G The world is bitokened the see. That the thridde part bicame blod bitokeneth that o part of panymes dwellen in her synnes of misbilevyng. That the thridde part of creatures benn deedG bitokeneth of hem that ben turnedG to the bileve that shulen ben lorneG a gret part, thourgh wicke life that thei lovedenT in wicke workis that thai doun. Bi the schippis ben bitokened prelatisG in this world that shulden beren the othereG to the reversG T of savacioun. A gret part shulen be lorn of hem.

[10] And the thridde aungele blewe his trumpe, and a greet sterre fel fro heven brennand as a brondeG and tok the thride part of the rivers and fel into wellis. [11] And the name of the sterre is seide Wermwede,G and the thridde part of the watris is maad wermwed,G and manyeT shul die of the watris for the biternesse.

Bi the watris ben bitokenede holi writt of the olde lawe and of the newe. Bi the wellis ben bitokened the gospelis. That the sterre felle and maade hem bitter bitokened that after Jhesu Crist hadde taughte the right bileve in holi chirche thurgh holi writ and is resceyvede, the devel made heretikis to woxenG more and more and corumpenG holi writ thurgh false understondynge and evel techynge and maken hem alle bitter as wermwede and lestG manyeT of that techyng.

[12] And the ferthe aungele blew his trumpe, and the thridde part of the sune and of the moone and of sterris is smyten with derknes so that o part schon not night ne day. [13] And I sawe and herde an egle fleegh thurgh the heven and seide with gret vois, “Wo, wo, wo to hem that wonenG in erthe.”T

That the thridde part of the sunne and mone and sterris ben smyten in derknesseT bitokeneth hem that the fyndeG may not blynden thurgh mysbileve. He binymethG hem grace [fol. 214r] thurgh evel werkis bothe of the grete and of the smaller and of the smallest so that thai amenden hem nought thourgh helthe ne thurgh harmes that thai han, that bitokeneth day and nyght. Bi the egle ben bitokened prechours that comen fro fereG and warnen holi chirche of gret tribulaciouns that it shal han at the commynge of Anticrist, nameli to hem that han goven over myche her love alle to ertheli thingis.

div.head: Chapter 9
div.ab: [1] And the fifte aungele blew his trumpe, and I saugh that a sterre feel fro heven to erthe, and hym was goven the keiye of the depe pit.G N [2] And he opened the pit and the smoke of the pit went up as a grete ovene and maade the sune derk and the erthe.T [3] And out of the smok came locustus into the erthe, and hym was goven power to don harm as the scorpioun. [4] And hem is comaundid to do non harme to the heighG of the erthe, neither no greneG nether no tree ne no man but hem that hadden not the mark of God in here forhedis, [5] and bad that thei shulden not slen hem but turmenten hem fyve monethis,G and her turment is as the turment of scorpions whan he smytethG man. [6] And in tho dayes, men shulen seken deeth and thei shulen not fynden it, and thai shulen desiren to dien and deeth shal fleen fro hem.

Bi the sterre that fel fro hevene bitokeneth the fendis that opened the pite of the deippeG T that is the sotileG eresieG that ben in the eretikis discipils.T The smoke that derketh the sunne bitokeneth the evel techynge that thai techen that maken derk the bileve. Bi tho that mow not fleen higheG ben bitokened Antcristis discipils that mowe not fleen highe thurgh right undirstondynge ne gon not sikirliG thurgh goode werkes. Bi the heighG and the grene and the trees ben bitokened thre degreesT in holi chirche: tho that be newe comen to the bileve, and tho that werken wele,G and tho that ben of heighG lif,N T that oure Lord wil not suffre that thai ben harmedT in soule, though he sende hem tribulacioun to the bodi. That thei desiren the deeth bitokeneth the grete drede that the gudG shulen han to comen and to fallen in tribulaciouns that shul be so gret.

[7] And locustus semen as it weren horsG that weren dightG to baitaile and on her heides thai han corounes that semen as it were gold, and her faces as mennes faces. [8] And thei shulen han hereG as it were of a woman, and her teeth as of a leoun [9] and haburiounesG T as it [fol. 214v] were of yren, and the woisG of here wengis as the vois of charesG of manye hors that rennen into bataile. [10] And thei shulen han tailis as the scorpion and scharpe prikisG in herT tailis, and her myghte is to grevenG the folk fyve monethes. And thei han [11] a kynge overe hem, the aungele of the pit to whome the name in Ebrewe is Abadoun, in Greke Apollion, in Latyn Exterminans.G N T
[12] And thane passith o wo, and yit comen two woes.T

By the hors dight to batayle is bitokened the pridde and the cruelté that ben in Anticristis prophetis. Bi the corownesT that semen as it were gold and that thei that hadden faces as it were of men, that is bitokened two manere of ypocrisye, onG his in herte techyng, another in her lyvynge. And that thai han heris as it were a womman bitokeneth that thai ben nescheG and lightG to turne to evel. Bi the teeth as a leoun is bitokened her bileve. Bi the habiriounesT as it wern of iren is bitokened the hard hertis that thai han agenG sothefastnesse.G Bi the soun of her wengis is bitokened the gret pride that thai haven of her science.G That thai haven the tailis as of the scorpion ben bitokened worldly thingis that thei haven.

[13] And the sixte aungele blewe his trumpe, and I herde a vois of the foure corneresN of the auter of gold that is bifore Goddis eyen [14] that seide to the sext aungele, “Unbynde the foure aungelis that ben boundunn in the flood of Eufraten.”G [15] And the foure aungelis ben unboundunn that were redi to sleen the thride part of men, and bi an oure and bi a day and bi a moneth and bi a yeer.N [16] And I saugh many thousande knyghtis on hors, and I herde her noumbre, twenti thousende sithisG T ten thousende.

[17] And thei hade haburiounesT of fire and of jacinitG and of brenneston,G and the hedes of the hors weren as hedis of leonnes, and out of her mouthe camen fire and smoke and brunstoun [18] thurgh whiche the thride part of men weren slaun. [19] For the myght of hors is in her mouthes, and in her taylis that semen neddris.G T

The auter of gold bitokeneth the flesche of Jhesu Crist. Bi the foure corneris bitokeneth the foure gospelleris that drowen ofG foure thingis oure savacioun: the Nativité of oure Lord, the Passioun, the Resureccioun, the Assencioun. And the foure aungelis that ben in the gret flode of Eufrate that the voice bad unbynden bitokeneth the princes on foure half the world. The undoynge is the suffraunce that oure Lord suffreth hem to mysdonG that tyme. [fol. 215r] For aforhondeG shulen preche priveli,G and after thei wiln putten hem forth apertliG agenG holi chirche. The hors bitokeneth the tirauntis of this world, the knyghtis the eretikis that maken the other to mysdoun thurgh her techynge. Bi the fire that cam out of the hors mouthis ben bitokened coveitiseG to whiche turneth of prechynge of eretikis. Bi the smok is pride bitokened, bi the brunstoun lecherie. Bi these foure synnes be corumpidG a gret hepG T of the folk in this world,T that is to seie eresie, coveitise, pride, and lecherie. That the myght of the hors ben in ther mouthis and in her tailis ben bitokened that thourgh false techyng and wikeG werkis and thourgh evel exsaumple, thei gilenG the other.

[20] And these other men that ben not slayn in these woundisG N and that takith not penaunce of the werkis of her hondis, and that thei honored notG the devel ne ymagerie of gold ne of silver ne of bras ne of ston ne of trees that mow not seen ne heren ne goun,G [21] ne takenn no penaunce of ther mensleyngisG ne of her venym doyngisG ne of her fornicaciounsT ne of her thiftis.

div.note: tho that mow not fleen highe, those that cannot fly high (the locusts)
honored not, did not stop worshipping

div.head: Chapter 10
div.ab: [1] And I sawe another aungele comende doun fro heven covered with a cloude and the bow of hevenG in his hede and his face was as the sune and his feet as pilerersG of fire [2] and hade in his hond a book open and sette his right foot on the see and his lifte foot on the erthe [3] and cried with gret vois as a leoun whan he roreth.T And to his crie spaken seven thundris her voisses. [4] And I herde a vois of heven that seide to me, “MarkeG T the wordis of the seven thundres and writ hem not.”

The aungele comende doun fro heven bitokeneth Goddis Sone that lowed hymG to the kyndeG of mann. The cloude bitokeneth the flesch that he tok of oure ladi Marie. The aungele bitokeneth the acorde and the byndynge bitwene God and mann. Bi the face ben bitokened goode menn of religioun that ben likened to hym in hardinesseG of lif. Thei ben as the sunne for thei lightenn the othere thurgh goode exsaumple. Bi the feetT ben bitokenede the good prechoures that gon fro o place to anothere to prechen the bileve. Thei ben pilerers of fire and thei owenG to susteyne the febleG and undirnymmynG the colde and hetenG hem with fier of love. That he had a book in his honde bitokeneth that he seith in the gospel, “I am not come to brek the law, but I am [fol. 215v] comen to fulfillen it.”N That the book was open bitokeneth that he openethG holi writte thurgh his comyngeT and gaf understondynge to his chosene. Bi the see is understonden hethen men,T bi the erthe the Jewis. To turneG to bileve the hethen men, he sente his stronge prechours, that is bitokened bi the right foot, and to the Jewis the febled, and that is bitokened the lift fott. And that he cried as a leoun when he roreth bitokeneth that thurgh his prechynge he holdith hise in here bileve, that thai dure,G not gon out.G Bi the seven thundris that answerden to his crie, hereG voises bitokenede the goode prechours in holi chirche after apostils. That the vois saide that he shuld heeleG N that the thundris spaken and that he write hem not is bitokened that at the commyng of Anticrist, the prechynge of the gospel shal sesen.G

[5] And the aungele that I sooG saugh stonde on the see and on the erthe liftid up his honde in to hevene [6] and swor bi hym that liveth withouten ende that made hevene and erthe and see and alle thingis that therinne ben that tyme shal last no lenger. [7] But to the tyme of the seven aungele whane he schale bigyne to blaweG T shal be endide the privetisG of God, as he has prechid bi his holi prophetis and his servantis.
[8] And the vois that I herde fro heven eftG spak to me and seide, “Go and take the book that is open of the aungelis hond that stant on the see and on the erthe.”

[9] And I wente to the aungele and bad hym takeG me the book. And he seide to me, “Tak and sweleweG it in, and it shal maak thi wombeG bitter, but in thi mouthe it shal be swete as hony.” [10] And I tooke the book of the aungelis hondT and swelewed it in,T and it was swet in my mouthe as hony and in my wombe bitter.

Bi the liftyngT up of the aungelis honde is bitokened the upstiyng of oure Lord. Bi that that he swore that the world shulden lasten no lenger and the privetés of Gode schulden ben endide bihotithG T the stedfast bileve of glorie that oure Lord gyveth to hem that ben in persecucioun of Anticrist. The book open that the aungele held in his honde bitokeneth hem that desiren the understondynge of holi write and taken itG God comaundith hem that thei do it in werke. That the book was maad [fol. 216r] swete in his mouthe and bitter in his wombe bitokeneth that Goddes wordT is plesant to man to hern it and prechen it, but it is ful herdG to doon in werk.

div.note: gon out, fall away from faith

div.head: Chapter 11
div.ab: [10:11] And also the aungele seide to me, “Thou mostG prechen to manye diverce folkis and to many kyngis.”T

[11:1] And he gaf me a reed that semed as it were a yerdeG and seide to me, “DightG thee and meteG the temple and the autere and hem that honorenG therinne. [2] The porcheG T that is withouten the temple, cast it oute. Mete it not, for it is gove to misbilevendeG N that shal defoulen the holi citee two and fourti monethis.”

Bi the reed that semed as it were a yerde is bitokenede holi writ, bi the yerde chastisynge of flesche that thai owen to havenG that knouen holi writ and prechynge as the apostille Seynt Poule seith, “I chastise my bodi and make it sogetG to my soule, lest happeliG whan I preche to othere I be maad reprevable.”G N T That he bad hym risen to mete the temple bitokeneth that the prechours owen to drawen hem to goode werkis and prechen to othere after that thei mowen undirstonde and joynenG hem penance after that thei mowen bere.G Bi the porche withoute the temple is understonden bi fals Cristen men to whom men owen not to prechen of the comyng of Anticrist but puten hem out thurgh techynge.N That thei misbilevende shulen han myght to defoulen the citee two and fourti monethis bitokeneth that Antecrist shal han power to defoulen holi chirche with manye percecuciouns three yere and an half, that isT the tyme that is tolde biforn. Bi an houre, that is bitokened bi half a yere, and bi a day a yere, by a moneth a yere, and byT a yer a yeer. And that shale be sette bifornG bi two tymesT and half a tyme.N

[3] “And I shale gyve to myT two witnessis, and thei shulen prechen bi a thousende dayes tooG hundridT and sixti, coveredT with sackis.”G [4] Thes ben two olyvesG and two candilstikis stondenT in the sighte of the Lorde of erthe. [5] And who that wile noienG hem, fire shal come out of hir mowthis and shal devoren her enmyes. And who that wil do them harm, the fire of her mouthe shal slenT hem. [6] Thei han power to close hevene that it reyne not in the dayes of her prophecie, and thai han powers on watres to turnen hem into blod and to smyte the erthe with eche woundeG hou often thei wiln.T

These two witnessis ben Enok and ElieN that bitokeneth prechours to whomT oure Lord sendith his grace and monestithG that thei faile not in so litil [fol. 216v] wo whan thei durenG in so great persecucioun. That thei weren covered with sackis bitokenen that prechours and prelatis owen to gyven othere exsaumple to do penance. That thei ben two olyves bitokeneth that thei shul be ful of merci. That thei ben candilstikis schynynge bitokeneth that thei shulen lighten the othere thourgh holi techynge and thourgh good ensaumple. That thei ben stondende bitokeneth that thei shul not taken of ertheli thingis but for her sustinaunce, as the apostile Seynt Poule seith, “If that we han that we may be feedG with and hilid,G be we paiedG with that.”N That the fiere shal comen out at her mouthis and devoren her enmyes bitokeneth that thei shulen fighten with gostli swerd that is Goddis word that is fire, not thurgh erthli myght. Bi the reyn of heven bitokeneth the manasG of the proude mightiT that good prechours han myghte to closenG that thei be not drede.N Bi the watres ben bitokened the lecherous that the goode prechours turnen into blood whan thei maken hem to ben aknoweG ther filthis. Bi the erthe is bitokened coveitise that the godd prechours smyten with alle woundis whan thei doun hem forsake the yvel and suffren alle manere myseseG for the love of God.

[7] And whan thei han endide her witnesse, the bestG that cometh up of the depnesse shal fighte with hem and overecomen hem and shal sleen hem. [8] And her bodies shulen lyn in the gret citee that is gosteli clepid Sodom and Egipte, thereG that here Lorde was donG on the rood. [9] And men shul seen her bodies aboven erthe three dayes and an half. And thei shul not suffre that thei be leide in erthe. [10] And thei that wonen in erthe shulen joienG and gladen of hem and senden giftis the oenG to the othere, for these two prophetis turmentiden hem that wonen in erthe.

[11] And after thes thre dayes, the gostG of lyf shul entre onto hem thurgh God, and thei shul stonden on her fete, and alle that shulen seen this shulen han gret drede [12] and shulen heren a gret vois fro hevene that shalle seiye to hem, “Cometh up hider.” And thei shulen weendenG up in a clowde, and her enmyes shul seen hem.

[13] And in that tyme shal be maad a gret erthe movynge,G T and the tenthe part of the citee shal fallen, and ther ben slayn in erthe stirynge the names of men seven thousende.T And the othere be sent into drede and gyven heryingeG to God of heven.
[14] And than endith the tother wo, and the thride wo shul come sone.

Bi the [fol. 217r] best that came out of the pit bitokeneth Anticrist that shal come agenG Enoc and Elie and shal slen hem, and it bitokeneth the fend that cometh up thurgh her hertis that ben derk thurgh synne agen Goddis folk that doun hem harme in ertheli thingis as he dide Job.N The grete citee bitokeneth the world that is cleped Sodom gosteli,T that is an othereG T to herien God, and Egipt that is a derknesse, that is that hath no knowing of God. The bodies of Elie and Enok shul be seen lyynge in stretis dead, that bitokeneth that the folk of the world shulen ben agastG of the advercitees and angwische that Goddis halowisG shulen suffren. But that is wronge, for the Lord of halewis was turmentid and dounG on the roode. That thai suffreden not to birienG the bodies bitokeneth that the folk han no remembraunce of the holiG that han ben. And that thei gladeden of her deeth and thei senten eche to othere bitokeneth that ech gladeth whan thei seen worldly goodisT fallen fro a gud man that was wont to chastise hem of her wickednesse, and seyn the oon to the othere, “Now we ben vengid of this papelard.”G That the gost of lif schal entre into hem bitokeneth that thai dieden for the love of God shale risse to blisse. That thai stoden on her fete bitokened the stedfastnesse that thei have, that no man may don hem harm. That thei wenten up in a cloude bitokeneth that the flesche is glorifiede. The stirynge of the erthe bitokeneth the grete drede that the tirauntis shulen han that turmenten hemT in this lyf. That the tenthe part of the citee fel bitokeneth the dampnacioun of hem that weren asignedeG as clerkis and prelatisT in the world that be slayn. The stirynge of the erthe bitokeneth the simple folk that ben lornG thurgh these othere. That thes othere ben aferd and yelden glorie to God bitokeneth that echoonG schulen be chastised bi the other and don her penaunce mekeli.G
[15] And the seventh aungele blew his trumpe and made his gret cry in heven that seide, “Made is the ryngeG of this world oure Lord and Jhesu Cristis his Sone. He shale rynge withouten hende.”G

[16] And the foure and twenti olde that sitten on seges biforn Godis face fellenN and honoureden hym and seiden, [17] “We yelden grace to thee, oure Lord God almyghti, that art and shal ben and hast resseyved vertu and hast regned. [18] And the folk ben wroththe, and thi wraththe is comen and thi tyme to jugen the deade and yelde mede to [fol. 217v] thin halewis, prophetis,T and otherT that dreden thi name, litil and mochel,G and distroyen that filenG the erthe.”

The grete vois in hevene bitokeneth the gret joye that holi chirche shal han aftir Anticrist is fordoun,G of the peesG than that schal be gove to hir.T Bi the foure and twenti grete ben bitokened the prelatis of holi chirche. That theiT fellen on knees and worschipiden God bitokeneth that thei lowen hemG to do penaunce in this lif and thankeden God of the goodis that he hath geve hem and that he hath deliverid hem of her enmys.

div.note: owen to haven, ought to receive (owe as a debt)
after that thei mowen bere, according to what they can bear
shale be sette biforn, will be written later
myghte to closen, power to shut out

div.head: Chapter 12
div.ab: [11:19] And the temple of God in hevene is opene and whiccheT of his testamentG is comen into his temple, and lettingisG ben maade and voisesG and thundres and erthe movyngeT and haile.T

[12:1] And a greet tokeneG in hevene aperide,N T a womman coverede with the sunne and the moone undir hire fete and on hire hede a coroune with many sterris,T [2] and grete with childe, and cried and was turmentid in childe berynge.

The hevene bitokeneth holi chirche. The temple of God bitokeneth the Holi Gost that aperede inT holi chirche, thurgh whiche the privetés of God ben schewede. The whiccheT of his testament bitokeneth Jhesu Crist, thurgh whiche his hestisG ben feld.G The lightnynge bitokeneth his miraclis. The vois bitokeneth the predicaciouns,G the stirynge of erthe tribulaciounsT that oft comen and gon. The woman bitokeneth holi chirche that is clade with Jhesu Crist that is the sunne thourgh his grace. Bi the moone that is under hir fete bitokeneth ertheli thingis wherwith holi chirche owith to be susteyned in this dedeli lyf and owithG not coveiten, the twelve sterres tho holi soulis that ben wonnen thourgh apostlis,T and the heed of holi chirche is Jhesu Crist. The seed that sche was gret with bitokeneth Goddis word. The angwische that sche had to beren childe bitokeneth the scharpnesse of lif that the holi prechours hadden to converten othere. The crie bitokeneth prechynge.

[3] And anothere token is seen in heven, a grete dragoun reedG that hadde seven hedis and ten hornes.N [4] And his taile drowG doun the thride part of the sterris of heven and haddeG T hem into the erthe. And the dragoun stode biforn the womman that shuld childenG to devoren hir childe whan it was borun. [5] And sche childide a knaveG childe that was to governe alle men in yerde of iren.G And [fol. 218r] hir childe is ravyschideG to God and to his trone. [6] And the womman fleighG into desert. There sche had a stedG dighteG of God. Ther men shal feden hir a thousande and two hundride and sexti dayes.

The dragon bitokeneth the fend that is of gret power and is reed thurgh slaughter. Bi the seven hedis ben bitokened seven tirauntis thourgh whiche he wirkith that ben the seven hed synnes,G N the ten hornes the richesse of the world wherwith the princis putten dounG the Ten Comaundementis.T Bi the taile that drowgh doun the thride part of the sterris of heven bitokeneth leccherie, thurgh whiche he makith miche folk to be lorun.G That he sendith hem to the erthe bitokeneth that he settith coveitiseG to meynteynenG lecherie. That the dragon stode bifore the womman to devoren hir childe bitokeneth that the devele is ever redi and waytith to devoren childerT thourgh synne whan thei ben borun thurgh baptem.N The knave child bitokeneth Jhesu Crist that is borun of holi chirche for that he governeth the folk with right and is ravyschide to God his Fadir at his upstiynge.G That the womman flede into desert bitokeneth that holi chirche departith hir fro delites of this world and the noise into life of penaunce, and there fedith God gostli with brede as many dayes as amounten thre yeer and an half that Anticrist regneth. That is alle the dayes of this lif, for so long the devele hath power to grevenG mann.

[7] And a grete bataile is maade in hevene, and Michael and his aungelis foughten with the dragoun. [8] And the dragon and his aungelis myghten not agenstondenG T hym, and thei shule never more be seen in hevene. [9] And this grete dragoun, the olde eddreG that is cleped the devel and Sathanas that disceyveth alle the world, is caste into the erthe, and his aungelis ben sent with hym.

[10] And I herde a grete vois of hevene that seide, “Now is helthe and vertu and kyngdam of oure God and myght of Jhesu Crist. And the accuseris of oure bretheren ben cast doun that accuseden hem bifore Goddis face day and nyght. [11] And thei overcamen hem thurgh the blode of the Lombe and thourgh the word of his witnesse. Thei han not lovede her soulisT unto the deeth. [12] Therfor glade yee, hevenes and that wonenG in hem, and wo to the erthe and see, for the devel is comen doun to you with gret wraththe and wotG that he hath littil tyme.”

That the grete bataile is doun in heven ageneG the grete dragonT bitokeneth that whanne the feende asaylith [fol. 218v] holi chirche, Goddis aungelis comen fro heven doun toT helpen us and overcomen hym. That the dragon is cast into erthe and his aungelis with hym bitokeneth that whane the devele temptith holi men in holi chirche and wendith awey overcomenG for that thei ben amendid thourgh her temptaciouns, that he asaileth men and wymen that han sette to her hertis in erthli thingis. He asaileth hem the harder and the scharplyerG T for that he is agreved that he is overcomen. The gret vois in hevene is the joyes and the graces that holi chirche yeldith to God whan the fende is overcomen and his temptaciouns thourgh meknesse.T And that greved the feend, for he is overcomen thourgh the Passioun of Jhesu Crist and thurgh the bileve and thourgh penaunce. That the vois seide that the devele was come doun with gret wraththe that he hath litil tyme bitokeneth that ech old man and woman owith strongli to kepenT hem, for the nerG that thei neighenG ther deeth, the more he agreveth the fende and the more isG aboute to encombrenG hem with synne. For than hath he besteG tyme, for his tyme is schortest.N

[13] And whane the dragoun saugh that he was cast into the erthe, he pursuedT the woman that bare the knave childe. [14] To the woman is geven two wingis of an ecleeG to fleen into desert into hir stede,G thereG sche is noreschideG bi a tymeT fro the face of a serpent. [15] And out of his mouthe the serpent sent a water as it were a flode after the woman to maken hir bytrapedG of the flode.T [16] And erthe halpeG the woman and opened his mouthe and swelewideG the flod that the dragoun sent out at his mouthe. [17] And the dragoun was wrothe to the woman and wente and faughte with hir kyndeG that kepten Godis comaundementis and han witnesse of Jhesu Crist, [18] and stode hymself on the graveleG of the see.T

That the dragoun faughtT with the woman after he was cast into erthe bitokeneth thowgh the fende be onesG overcomen, he lettith notG to asailen another tyme. Bi the two wenges of the egle that ben gove to the womman bitokeneth the two lawis thourgh whicheT techyng holi chirche doithT penaunce and put hir ferG fro the serpent, cast out at his mouthe after the woman resceyvedeT in holi chirche. That the erthe opened bitokeneth holi men that ben in erthe thourgh holinesseT and stedfastnesse and priers fordonG the tribulaciouns that the fende sendith sumtymeG in holi chirche, that he may not distroien hir bi tribulacioun.T [fol. 219r] That the erthe opened, that ben the coveitous that swelewen the richesse that the good men of holi chirche letenG and lyven in povert and given to kepeG to hem.T That the dragoun wrathe to the woman and goth and fightith with othere of hir kynde bitokeneth that I seide biforn: whan he asailith goode men of highG lif and thei agenstondenG T hym, that he goith to men of lowerG lyf and temptith hem the harder that ben in the bileve of Jhesu Crist. And kepen hemG out of deadli synne and hem overcometh he not,G but oneli hym that ben ydil in goode werkis. That is bitokened that he restith on the gravele of the see.

div.note: whicche of his testament, Ark of his Covenant
seven hed synnes, Seven Deadly Sins
hem overcometh he not, he does not overcome them

div.head: Chapter 13
div.ab: [1] And I saugh a bestG comynge out of the see that had sevene hedis and ten hornesse and on the ten hornes ten diademes, and on his hedis names of blasfemye.T [2] And the best was like to a liberdeG and hadde feete as a bereG and mouthe as a leoun. And the dragoun gaf hym his power and his vertuG and his gret myght.

That the best came out of theT see bitokeneth that the fende takith felaschipe of the princes of the world, and with hem he strengthith his bataile agen holi chirche, that is goode Cristen men. Bi that that the best semede as a liberde of divers coloursN bitokeneth the eretikis and ypocritis that ben of divers undirstondingis in her errours and in her wikidnesse and semen goode withouten.G Bi the feet as a bere bitokeneth these ravenours.T Bi the mouthe as a lyoun bitokeneth the manacesG of proude men and myghti.T That the dragoun gaf the best his vertu and his grete power bitokenethT that the fend shal putten in Anticrist and in his discipils as myche evel as he may to noyenG T othere. And hym is geven power two and fourti monethis.N

[3] And I sawe oen of the hedis of the best as it were slayn, and the heede deedeG was helidT and all the othere wondreden and foloweden the best [4] and worschippiden hym and the dragoun, for he gave suche power to the best, and seiden, “Who is liyk to the best?T And who myght fighten with hym?”

[5] And hym is goven leveG to speken loude and to gyve blas|femy [fol. 219v], and power is gove to hym to doonT evel two and fourty monethis. [6] And the best opened his mouthe into blasfemyes agen God to blasfemen his name and his tabernacleT and hem that wonen in hevene. [7] And hym is goven leve to do bataile with the holi and overecomen hem. And hym is goven power in alle kyndis and in alle langages of men. [8] And alle that wonen in erthe shulen honorenG hym, whiche that the names ben not written in the book of lyf of the Lomb that is slayn fro the bigynnynge of the world.
[9] He that hath eres, here. [10] He that ledith into caitifté,G T into caitifté shal go. He that with swerdT sleith motG be slayn with swerd.

The best that semede deede and slayn bitokeneth Anticrist that shal feynenG hym as he were deede and shal comen agene the thridde day to lyf and thourgh that many folk schullen bileven that he is God and shulen honouren hym and the feend in hym. That hym is gove leve to speke loude bitokeneth that he schal seyn that he is God and thourgh enchauntement he schal make that the develis ber hym up into the sky as if he went up to hevene. That hym is gove leve to do bataile with the holi and overcome hem bitokeneth that oure Lord gave hym leve to tormenten the bodi of holi men and wymmen in his tyme to heghenG her soules. As it is written in Job, “The erthe is goven into the hondis of the unpitous.”G N T That thei that wonen in the erthe schullen ben obedientT to hym, that bitokeneth hem that ben gyven toG myche to worldli richesse. That her names ben nought writen in the book of lyf bitokeneth that thei coumforten hem not in the cros. That the Lomb is slayn fro gynnynge of the world bitokeneth that oure Lord and his chosen weren tormentid from the gynnynge of the world, as in Abel the first man that was sclaynn.G N That he biddith us that we drede no bodili peyne ne geve noon evel ensaumple to other, for evel doeris shulen han peyne, and thei that suffren peyne and tormentis and persecuciouns in pacience [fol. 220r], thei schullenT han heigh coroun for here stedfast bileve and suffrance.N

[11] And I saugh anothere best comynge out of the erthe and hadde two hornes as it were of the Lomb, and spak as the dragoun, [12] and dide al the myghtG of the tother best that was helid of the wounde of deth, [13] and dide manye miraclis, and dide the fier come doun fro hevene into erthe that alle men myghte seen, [14] and disceyvede hem that weren in erthe for the miracles that hym is gove leeve to dounG in the sighte of the beste, and seideG to hem that wonedenG on erthe that thei madenG a ymage of the best that hath the wounde with the swerd and liveth. [15] And to the ymage of the best he gaf a spirit and made hym to speken, and bad that alle that honouredenG not that best shulden be slayn. [16] Litil and myche, riche and pore, free and bonde,G he comaundide that alle schulden han the marke of the best in the right honde or in the forhede, [17] and no man myght bienG or sellen but if he hade the marke of the best or his name or the noumbre of his name.T
[18] Heer is wisdam. Whoso kan undirstonden, telleN heG the name of the best, for the noumbre of man is and his noumbre is vic, lx, and vi.G T

Bi the best that cam out of the erthe ben bitokened the techyng of Antecristes disciplis that given hemT to prechyng for ertheli goodis. That he had two hornes bitokeneth the two lawis of God that thei schulen falsli han, eitherG it bitokeneth clene lyf and rightful techinge that thei shuld do men to understonden that thei han and han it not. That he spak also as the dragoun bitokeneth that her prechinge schal be to disceyven othere as the serpent disceyved Eve.N That he dide fier fallen into the erthe among folk bitokeneth that thei shulen do men to understonde that the Holi Gost descendith in hem in the liknesse of fierN as it dide in Jhesu Cristis discipils. But thei schulen doon it openli, and Jhesu Cristis discipils diden it priveli. And bi these wonynge in erthe is bitokened these men and wymmen that setten her hertis in ertheli thingis. Bi the ymage of the best is bitokened the [fol. 220v] false profetisT that doon bi the counseils and the enticementis of hem that seken erthli thingis. That he gyveth power to the best to speke bitokeneth the power that thei han to misdounG thourgh enchesonG of her dignité.G That thei ben slayn that wolen not onouren his ymage bitokeneth that thei schulen cursen hem that wolen not consenten to the fals prelatis and wickid. That the beste dide marken alle in hir ryght hond or forhede bitokeneth that alle shulen folowen Anticrist and nowT gyven hem to his prelatis that doone her synne of leccherie priveli, and thane han thei his mark in her hond and afterward openli. And thane thei han the marke in the forhedeT and than shal no mann spekenT of God.N That no man may bien no sellen but if he have the marke or the name of the best bitokeneth that noon schal han power in holi chircheT to gyve londis ne rentis ne resceyveN but yif he have the marke of his kynrede, that is to seie that he be comen of gret kynrede or that he be in gret lordis servyse or that he be come therto thurgh symonyeG or he go to the ordreG to han bodili delites. Alle these ben Anticristis discipils and his ypocritis and eretikis.N That he seith the noumbre of his name of sixe hundrid sixti and sixe bitokeneth also as it doth Godis Sone and his comynge to saven us, that was and is verrey light that lighteth alle that wolen bileven in hym thourgh his grace. Ryght so the sone of perdicioun whan he schal come to disceyven the folk and leden hem to perdiciounT shal be cleped light falsli for the vertuG that he shal do and for the ensaumplis that he shal gyven. The noumbre of his name: D bitokeneth fyve hundrid, C an hundrid, L fifti, X ten, V fyve, I on.G And do the I bitwene D and the C, thane is it dic.G And the V betwene the L and the X, and thane is it lux,G T that is “to sei light,” for Anticrist shal falsli bi clepid light, as Jhesu Crist is clepid sothfastG light.N

div.note: dide al the myght, exercised all the power
vic, lx, and vi, six hundred, sixty, and six

div.head: Chapter 14
div.ab: [1] And I saugh a Lomb stondynge on the mount of Syon and with hym an hundrid and fourti [fol. 221r] and foure thousand that han the name of the Lombe and the name of his Fader writen in her forhedes. [2] And I herd a voice of hevene as it were the vois of manye watris and as gretT thundre, and that vois that I herde was as of harperis harpynge in her harpis, [3] sungen as it were a newe song biforn the sege and the foure bestis and the foure and twenti gret. And noon myghte seynG that ilkeG song but the hundrid and foure and fourti thousand that ben bought fro the erthe. [4] Tho ben thei that ben not defoulid with wymmen; thei ben virginis. Thei folowen the Lomb there that he goth.G [5] And lesyngG is not founden in her mouthis, and thei ben withoute wemG biforun the trone.

By the Lomb is bitokened Jhesu Crist that is sacrified for us. By the mount Sion is bitokened holi chirch to whiche the Lomb cam to his body. Bi the hundrid and foure and fourti thousand that hadden the name of the Lomb and the name of his Fader in her forhedes ben bitokened the holi men and wymmen that ben in holi lyf that stedefastlyche holden the bileve of the Resureccioun and of the Trynité and meynteynnen it ageyn the tirauntis in this world. By the vois of many watris is bitokened hem that wepen her synnes in this lyf thourgh verréG repentaunce. The vois of gret thundir is bitokened hem that dreden God and the vois of the manasG of the jugement in this lyf and lettenG to doun evele for drede of God. The vois of hem that harpen bitokenen hem that loven God sweteliG in this lyf, and to comen to his love thei setten hem in penance of the goode men of religioun. The song that thei songen bitokeneth the joyis of paradis that evere is newe and fresch. That noon may syngen it but thei that ben take fro the erthe bitokeneth that noon hath delitT but thei that hopen in the Passioun of Jhesu Crist oure Lord. That thei ben not filidG with womman bitokeneth that thei han noon delit in fleschli filthis ne of the world. That thei folewen the Lomb bitokeneth that thei conformen her lyf to Jhesu Cristis lyf here in erthe. That no lesyng was founden in her mouthis [fol. 221v] bitokeneth that thei usidenG aright her tungis and taughten wel her neighboris thorough good techyng and thorough good ensaumple. That thei ben without wemmeG bifore the trone bitokeneth that thei ben clene in concience and also in clene lyf.

[6] And I sawgh another aungel fliynge in the middil ofT hevene that hath the gospel that alwey schal laste and preche to hem that sitten on the erthe and to alle folk and linage and langage and puple,T [7] and seide to hem with gret cri, “AnourithG oure God and worschipith hym and dredith hym, for the tyme of his jugement cometh. And honourith hym that made hevene and erthe, see and alle thingis that ben in hem and the wellis of watris.”

Bi that othere aungel that fligh thorough hevene ben bitokened the goode prechours that thorough the wyngis of good techyng and wel worchyngG bien hierG than othere in holi chirche and goun frome place to placeT to preche Goddis word for to come to the lyf that evere shal laste to alle men, and to love God and drede hym and letenG alle yvelis for his love, and worschip hym with gud lyf.T
[8] And anothere aungel folewide hym and seide, “Fallen is Babiloyne the greet citeeN that maade alle men drunken of the welleT of wraththe of his leccherie.”N T

[9] And the thride aungel folewide the tother and seide with gret crie, “Alle that onouren the beste and his ymage and resseiveth his mark in her hond ether in her forhede, [10] thei schulen drynk of the wyn of Goddis wraththe that is meynedG with clere wynn in the cuppeT of his wraththe and shal be turmentid with fier and with brymstoun bifore the aungele and bifore the Lomb. [11] The smok of her turment shal encreesse withouten ende. And thei schulen have no rest dai ne nyght that anourith the beest and his ymage and taken his merk.” [12] This is the pacience of holi chirche,T that keppen Goddis comaundementis and the feith of Jhesu.

Bi the secounde aungele that seide, “Fallen is Babiloyne” bitokeneth that the prechours warnen holi chirche and seien that to the folk of the world that is bitokened bi Babiloyne schulen falle in dampnacioun of bodies and of soulis for her synnes that thei doun and thorough yvel ensaumple that thei given, wherthoroughG thei maken [fol. 222r] the tother drunken. That the thridde aungele seide with greet vois that alle that onouren the beste and his ymage and alle that resseyven his mark in the hond ether in the forhedes, that thei schulen drynke of the wraththe of God, bitokeneth that alle that ben drawun to the fals techyng of Anticrist and conformith hym to the vices of his discipils, tho ben the false profetis and false clerkis that ben proud and coveitouse and leccherouse and losengouris,G N thei schulen drynk of the trobleG drynke of helle. And for the delite that thei haven here, thei schulen have the fier of helle for her brennyng coveitise that thei han here, and the stynk of helle for her lecherie that thei delitten hem inne that schal last withouten ende.

[13] And I herde a vois fro hevene that seide to me, “Writ thou: thei that dienG in oure Lord ben blissid for this tyme forth now, seith the Spirit, that thei resten of her travels,G for the werkes of hem suenG hem.”T

That the vois seith tho that dien in oure Lord ben blissid bitokeneth the soulis of the sothfast Cristen men that dien in sothfast schrift and sorewe of herte thorough deth comen to rest right so in hooli chirche. Thei that suffren tribulaciouns, sorewis, and angwischis, thei han gret joies in hereG T hertis. But be thei war herG of ther ben manye that gon frowardG God thorough tribulaciouns that thei han. And that her werkis schal folowe hem bitokeneth that oure swete Lord gyveth gretter blis than thei may disserve.

[14] And I saugh a whiyt ski,G and upon that cloude I saugh the maidenes sone MarieG T and hadde on his heede a coroun of gold and in his hond a scharp sikil. [15] And another aungele came out of the temple and cried with greet cri to hym that sat upon the cloude, “Sette thi sikil on the corn,G for the tyme of repyng is comen. For the corun of the erthe is ripe.” [16] And he that sat upon the cloude sette his sikil on the erthe and rapeG the erthe.

The whiyt cloude bitokeneth the clene fleisch of Jhesu Crist, either it bitokeneth the hooli whiche he restith hym inne and jugen with hym. Bi the coroun of gold is bitokened the kunnyng of God bi which he overcam the devel. Bi the scharp sikil is bitokened the jugement that is kervynge.G T Bi that other aungel ben bitokened tho men and [fol. 222v] wymmen. That theiT wenten out of the temple bitokeneth that thei schulen take her blis. That thai weren holdun litil bi in this world and unworthiN bitokeneth that thei desirenT the cumpeny of holi men and wymmen that ben in erthe and acorden toG the rightwisnesse of God. That the corn is alle ripe bitokeneth that the creuelté and malice of wickid men and wymmen is highed fer ynow.G That he settith his sikil in the erthe bitokeneth that oure Lord at the jugement schal depart the gode fro the yvele, and that is the corunT that he schal doG in his berne,G that is in blisse with hym. And thei that gyven hem stidfastli rotidG in ertheli thingis schulen be pullid up bi the rootis and cast into fier to brenne.

[17] Another aungel came out of the temple that is in hevene, and he hath a scharp sikil. [18] And another aungele came out of the auter and hath power over fier and water,T and cried with a greet crie to hym that hath the sikil, “Kit upG T the grapis of the vyn of the erthe, for thei ben ripe.” [19] And the aungel sette his sikil in the erthe and karf upT the vynes of the erthe and leide hem in the grete dicheG of the wraththe of God [20] and ben defoulidG outG of that citee. And there came out blood of the lakesG N to the bridil of horsis.G T

That othere aungele that hadde the scharp sikil as that othere first aungele bitokeneth that the holi seyntis schulen juge with oure Lord. Bi that othere aungel that came out of the auter and hath power over fier and watir ben bitokened the hegheste seyntisT as the postilsG and martris and confessourisG that maden sacrifice of her bodies and hadden power for to bynde and unbynde.N Bi the vyne, that bitokeneth hem that ben highe in kunnyngG in holi chirche, bi the erth the symple puple.T That he bad kerve up the vynes bitokeneth that men schal departeG the wickid fro the good at the jugement and donG hem to the greet pit of helle. The defoilyngG bitokeneth the gret paynes and the gret schame that thei schulen have that han taken high dignetéT and gyven her hertis to ertheli thingis and to wickid delite. That he seith oute of the citee bitokeneth that it is not peyne of Purgatorie, for it is evermore lastinge.N That the blod came out of the lake to the bridil [fol. 223r] of horsis bitokeneth that the peynes and the sorewis schulen stieG T up to hevene of hem that schulden kepe here othereG that ben her princes and grete prelatis, and othere that han cure of soulis,G N and that is the thousynde pasG and sixe hundrid.N T
